ABSTRACT Objective The aim of the study is to estimate trends in the prevalence and associated factors of noncommunicable disease (NCD) risk factors in adults from 2007 to 2020 in Cabo Verde. Design Populationbased crosssectional study. Setting Nationally representative samples of adult population in Cabo Verde from the 2007 and 2020 STEPwise approach to NCD risk factor surveillance (STEPS) surveys. Participants The sample included 1760 adults in 2007 and 3721 in 2020. Outcome measures Included fruit/vegetable consumption, low physical activity, sedentary behaviour, current tobacco use, hazardous alcohol use, diabetes, total elevated cholesterol, hypertension and overweight/obesity. Logistic regressions adjusted for sociodemographic factors were applied to estimate predictors of each of the nine NCD risk factors. Results Compared with participants in the study year 2007, participants in the study year 2020 had a significantly higher prevalence of low physical activity (adjusted OR (AOR): 2.21, 95% CI: 1.15 to 4.25) and overweight/obesity (AOR: 1.68, 95% CI: 1.26 to 2.23) and significantly lower rate of hypertension (AOR: 0.77, 95% CI: 0.64 to 0.93). Low physical activity (AOR: 1.61, 95% CI: 1.23 to 2.10), overweight/obesity (AOR: 2.59, 95% CI: 2.10 to 3.20), current tobacco use (AOR: 1.94, 95% CI: 1.36 to 2.75), hypertension (AOR: 5.45, 95% CI: 4.24 to 7.00), diabetes (AOR: 8.40, 95% CI: 4.65 to 15.18) and elevated total cholesterol (AOR: 4.58, 95% CI: 2.83 to 7.39) were more common among the 50–64yearolds. Being male increased the odds of current tobacco use (AOR: 3.64, 95% CI: 2.75 to 4.81) and hazardous alcohol use (AOR: 4.79, 95% CI: 3.15 to 7.27), and decreased the odds of low physical activity (AOR: 0.48, 95% CI: 0.39 to 0.58) and overweight/obesity (AOR: 0.47, 95% CI: 0.40 to 0.56). Conclusions Of the nine NCD risk factors evaluated from 2007 to 2020 in Cabo Verde, two increased (overweight/ obesity and low physical activity) and one decreased (hypertension). Several associated variables were identified for each individual NCD risk factor that can help in guiding interventions. INTRODUCTION Majority (>85%) of death attributable to noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) happen in low- income and middle income countries.1 In Cabo Verde, a small island lower middle income country (population 540 000) in Africa, the majority (70%) of deaths were attributable to NCDs,2 and life expectancy was 73.3 years and the literacy rate was 85%.3 Considering stark increases of NCDs in the sub- Saharan Africa region, it is important to gain an insight in the local determinants of NCDs.4 Against this backdrop, national community- based data on NCD risk factors among adults in Cabo Verde are needed.
In the population of Cabo Verde, 7% had diabetes and 25% had hypertension.2 Behavioural factors, including alcohol abuse, unhealthy diet, smoking and physical inactivity increase the risk of dying from a NCDs.1 In Cabo Verde, in 2016, 6% of adults engaged in harmful alcohol use, 9% were current smokers and 19% were physically inactive.2
STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY ⇒ The study used standardised methods and two repeat nationally representative community- based survey samples of adults in Cabo Verde. ⇒ A large number of behavioural and biological noncommunicable disease (NCD) risk factors were included in the analyses. ⇒ Biochemical analysis was only conducted on a subsample in the 2007 and 2020 Cabo Verde STEPwise approach to NCD risk factor surveillance surveys. ⇒ Some of the variables, such as marital status, intake of cholesterol lowering drugs and residence status, were not included in both surveys, and therefore could not be included in the analysis. ⇒ The study had a low response rate, which may have biased results through higher likelihood of healthy volunteer participation in the study.

Qualitative data collected in 2014 from urban areas in Cabo Verde show high accessibility and high rates of alcohol use.5 Among adult women in Cabo Verde 18.9% (8.5% in men) lived with obesity in 2010–16.6
In another island country in Africa in Comoros, among adults (25–64 years), the prevalence of diabetes was 8.5%,7 and the prevalence of overweight and obesity was 28.6% and 22.2%, respectively.8 In other African countries, for example, 16.5% had 3–7 NCD risk factors in the Malawi STEPwise approach to NCD risk factor surveillance (STEPS) survey in 2009,9 and 26.7% had 3–10 NCD risk factors in the Zambia STEPS survey in 2017.10 Several sociodemographic factors, such as older age,11–14 men,11 15 educational level11 15 and urban residence,14 15 have been found to increase the odds of multiple biological and behavioural NCD risk indicators. The aim of the study is to estimate trends in the prevalence and associated factors of NCD risk factors in adults from 2007 to 2020 in Cabo Verde.

sections.heading: METHODS Participants and procedures
sections.text:
Secondary data from two cross- sectional STEPS household surveys in Cabo Verde in 2007 and 2020 were
analysed.16 A three- stage probabilistic sampling process (district, household and individual) was carried out to randomly select one individual per household from the target population, 25–64 years in 2007 and 18–69 years in 2020 (in our analysis, the 2020 sample was restricted to people 25–64 years). Exclusion criteria included if individuals were unable to respond to the interview. Interviews and physical measurements were conducted by 17 teams each consisting of a supervisor (a person from the technical team), two interviewers and a health professional (a doctor, a nurse, a nutritionist and a laboratory technician). In 2020, the response rate for interview and physical measurement was 63.5% and for biochemical measures 56.5%.17
Following the ‘WHO three STEPS procedure’: step 1: administration of a structured questionnaire, step 2: blood pressure (BP) through the sphygmomanometer (OMRON), and anthropometric measurements using a digital scale (Seca) and a conventional stadiometer (Seca) and step 3: blood glucose and lipids using the CardioChek PA@system.17
The National Ethics Committee for Health Research and the Data Protection Commission (CNEPS) approved the study, and written informed consent was obtained from all participants.

sections.heading: Measures
sections.text:
Outcome variables NCD risk factors were included based on previous studies,9 11 12 18 as follows: Behavioural NCD risk factors: 1. Fruit/vegetable consumption (‘In a typical week, on
how many days do you eat fruits?’ ‘How many servings of fruit do you eat on one of those days?’ the questions were the same for vegetable intake) (inadequate fruit/ vegetable intake was defined as<5 servings per day).17 2. Low physical activity (defined as <600 metabolic equivalent of task- min/week) was assessed with the ‘Global Physical Activity Questionnaire’ (GPAQ),19 which asks questions on physical activity in three domains (work, transportation and leisure time), for example, ‘Does your work involve vigorous- intensity activity that causes large increases in breathing or heart rate like (carrying or lifting heavy loads, digging or construction work) for at least 10 min continuously?’ ‘In a typical week, on how many days do you do vigorous- intensity activities as part of your work?’ ‘How much time do you spend doing vigorous- intensity activities at work on a typical day? (hours/minutes)’. 3. Sedentary behaviour (defined as ≥8 hours/day)20 was assessed with one item from the ‘GPAQ’: ‘The following question is about sitting or reclining at work, at home, getting to and from places, or with friends, including time spent sitting at a desk, sitting with friends, traveling in car, bus, train, reading, playing cards or watching television, but do not include time spent sleeping. How much time do you usually spend sitting or reclining on a typical day?’ (hours/min).19

Hazardous alcohol use (≥7 in women and ≥14 in men standard drinks in the last week),21 (based on questions: ‘Have you ever consumed any alcohol such as beer, wine, liquor, punch, grog, whiskey or cider?’ ‘During each of the past 7 days, how many standard drinks did you have each day?’).17
Biological risk factors for NCD Diabetes: ‘fasting plasma glucose levels ≥7.0 mmol/L or ≥126 mg/dL, and/or currently taking insulin or oral hypoglycemic drugs’.”22
Total elevated cholesterol: ‘≥200 mg/dL; ≥5.18 mmol/L’.23
Hypertension: ‘systolic BP≥140 mm Hg and/or diastolic BP≥90 mm Hg or currently on antihypertensive medication’ (based on the last two of BP readings in this survey).22
Body mass index (BMI): ‘overweight/obesity (≥25.0 kg/ m2)’.22

sections.heading: Sociodemographic data
sections.text: Sex (male, female), age (coded 1=25–35 years, 2=36–49 years and 3=50–64 years), education (‘In total, how many years have you spent at school and in full- time study (excluding pre- school)?’ coded 1=0–4 years, 2=5–8 years and 3=9 or more years), adult members of the household (‘How many people 18 years and older, including yourself, live in your household?’ coded as 1=0–1, 2=2 and 3=3 or more adult household members) (household crowding is an indicator of lower socioeconomic status)24 and work status (‘Which of the following best describes your main work status over the past 12 months?’ coded 1=employed (government employee, non- government employee, self- employed), 2=unemployed (unemployed (able to work), unemployed (unable to work)), 3=homemaker and 4=other (non- paid, student and retired)).17

sections.text:
The proportion of NCD risk factors was grouped as based on previous studies,14 18 3–9 NCD risk factors (vs 0–2 risk factors). Descriptive analyses were performed calculating proportions of participants by study year and

Logistic regressions adjusted for sociodemographic factors (study year, age group, sex, education, number of adult members and work status) were applied to estimate predictors of each of the nine risk factors of NCDs. P<0.05 was accepted as significant, and missing values were discarded. Statistical analyses were performed with STATA software V.15.0, considering the complex study design.

sections.text: Participants were not involved in the design of the study, recruitment or conduct of the study.

sections.heading: RESULTS Sample characteristics
sections.text:
The sample included 1760 adults, with a median age of 35.0 years (IQR=29.0–43.0 years) in 2007 and 3721 adults median age of 38.0 years (IQR=31.0–48.0 years) in 2020.
The proportion of younger adults, level of education and those who were unemployed increased and the number of adults in the household decreased from 2007 to 2020 (see table 1).
Distribution of NCD risk factors from 2007 to 2020 The prevalence of individual NCD risk factors increased significantly for low physical activity from 19.1% in 2007 to 36.7% in 2020, and overweight/obesity from 36.8% in 2007 to 50.4% in 2020. There was a significant decrease in the prevalence of hypertension from 38.7% in 2007 to 34.2% in 2020. Among men, there was a significant decrease in hazardous alcohol use from 15.9% in 2007 to 10.2% in 2020, and among women, there was a significant decrease in inadequate intake of fruits/vegetables from 87.2% in 2007 to 74.9% in 2020, and current tobacco use from 9.3% in 2007 to 5.8% in 2020. The prevalence of diabetes, sedentary behaviour and elevated total cholesterol remained unchanged from 2007 to 2020. The proportion of having 3–9 and the mean number of NCD risk factors did not significantly change from 2007 to 2020 (see table 2).

Sociodemographic determinants of individual behavioural NCD risk factors Compared with participants in the study year 2007, participants in the study year 2020 had a significantly higher prevalence of low physical activity and overweight/ obesity and significantly lower rate of hypertension. Low physical activity, overweight/obesity, current tobacco use, hypertension, diabetes and elevated total cholesterol were more common in the 50–64- year- olds and inadequate fruit/vegetable intake, sedentary behaviour and hazardous alcohol use did not change with age. Being male increased the odds of current tobacco use and hazardous alcohol use, and decreased the odds of low physical activity and overweight/obesity. Higher educational levels were positively associated low physical activity, sedentary behaviour, overweight/obesity and negatively associated with inadequate fruit and vegetable consumption, current tobacco use, hazardous alcohol use and hypertension. Having two or three or more adult household members (lower economic status) was positively associated with overweight/obesity, and hypertension,
and negatively associated with current tobacco use and low physical activity. Compared with people who were employed, those who were unemployed had a higher odds of low physical activity, insufficient fruit/vegetable intake and current tobacco use, and compared with all other work status groups, those who were employed had a higher odds of overweight/obesity and physical activity (see tables 3–5).

sections.heading: DISCUSSION
sections.text:
We found that the proportion of 3–9 NCD risk factors among adults in Cabo Verde did not change significantly from 42.9% in 2007 to 45.7% in 2020. The prevalence of low physical activity and overweight/obesity increased significantly and the prevalence of hypertension decreased significantly between 2007 and 2020. The prevalence of inadequate fruit/vegetable intake, sedentary behaviour, current tobacco use, hazardous alcohol use, diabetes and elevated total cholesterol did not change significantly from 2007 to 2020. to the Cabo Verde NCD risk factor targets from 2007 to 202025 (eg, reduce hypertension prevalence to 42% by 2020 from 44% in 2007), a reduction of hypertension was achieved, while an increase or no reduction was achieved for obesity, diabetes, harmful alcohol use and tobacco use. There was no target for physical inactivity which increased from 2007 to 2020.25 According to the Global Nutrition Report,6 Cabo Verde had little or no progress in terms of diet- related NCD targets, including obesity.6 Some of the reduction of hypertension may be attributed to strengthened implementation of NCD programme in Cabo Verde including the WHO PEN primary care interventions addressing hypertension, etc.24 In unadjusted analysis, among men, there has been a reduction of hazardous alcohol use, which may be related to implementing multisector interventions to prevent alcohol and other substance abuse,26 as well as the training of primary healthcare professionals on preventing alcohol abuse and a presidential campaign on ‘Less alcohol, More life’.26 Furthermore, the per capita (≥15 years) alcohol consumption (in litres of pure alcohol) reduced from 7.6 in 2010
to 5.7 in 2016.27 In terms of current tobacco use, there was some reduction from 14.1% in 2007 to 11.9% in 2020, but this was insignificant. Although some tobacco control measures, such as mass media and advertising bans, are in place, there is no policy or weak measure regarding smoke- free environments, health warnings and taxation (cigarettes have not become less affordable between 2010 and 2020).28
Similar to previous trend studies in India,29 Mongolia30 31 and Iran,32 low physical activity and/or overweight/obesity increased over time. In our study, the prevalence of hypertension decreased over time, which is similar to Mongolia,33 while in India,29 South Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo34 and Mozambique,35 the prevalence of hypertension increased over time. In comparison to other African countries, the proportion of 3–9 NCD risk factors (42.9% in 2007 and 45.7% in 2020) in this study was higher than in Malawi (3–7 NCD risk factors, 16.5%)9 and in Zambia (26.7%, 3–10 NCD risk factors).10 The prevalence of overweight/obesity in 2020 (50.4%) and the prevalence of diabetes (5.1%) in 2020 was similar

in terms of overweight/obesity (50.8%) in another island country in Africa in Comoros but diabetes was lower than in Comoros (8.5%),7 8 and overweight/obesity was higher than in Malawi (26.5%)9 and Zambia (24.4%).10 The prevalence of hypertension (36.6% in 2020) was higher than in Malawi (32.9%)9 and in Zambia (18.9%),10 the prevalence of current tobacco use (11.9% in 2020) was lower than in Malawi (14.1% current smokers)9 and in Zambia (10.7% daily tobacco use),10 and the prevalence of insufficient fruit/vegetable consumption (76.8% in 2020) was lower than in Zambia (90.4%).10
The higher prevalence of substance use among men than among women,36 and the higher rate of overweight/ obesity among women than among men have been found in previous studies.12 18 As expected, 11–14 older age increased the odds of low physical activity, overweight/ obesity, diabetes, hypertension, elevated total cholesterol and also current tobacco use. Lower education was associated with insufficient fruit/vegetable intake, current tobacco use and hazardous alcohol use, while higher education was associated with low physical activity, sedentary behaviour and overweight/obesity. Lower economic status was positively associated with overweight/obesity, and hypertension, and being unemployed had a higher odds of low physical activity, inadequate fruit/vegetable intake and current tobacco use. These results show how the nine specific NCD risk factors can be targeted differently depending on sex, age, educational level, economic, and work status.
The results of the study may have implications for policy and practice on the prevention and control of NCD risk factors among adults in Cabo Verde. We found a large increase in the prevalence of overweight/obesity from 36.8% to 50.4% and low physical activity from 19.1% to 36.7%, implying that a large population is at increased risk of morbidity and mortality.1 According to WHO guidelines,37 ‘Adults should do at least 150–300 min of moderate- intensity aerobic physical activity; or at least 75–150 min of vigorous intensity aerobic physical activity; or an equivalent combination of moderate- and vigorousintensity activity throughout the week, for substantial health benefits’.
A high proportion (45.7%) of the study population had 3–9 NCD risk factors, meaning that many people had multiple NCD risk factors, requiring that health promotion reduces multiple behavioural NCD risk factors (such as unhealthy diet, physical inactivity, tobacco use and harmful alcohol use) and promote early detection, treatment and healthcare of NCDs at primary level.38

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
Based on two national community- based surveys in adults from 2007 to 2020 in Cabo Verde, we found that of the nine risk factors for NCD evaluated in the past 13 years, two increased (overweight/obesity and low physical activity) and one decreased (hypertension). Several factors associated with NCD risk factors were identified, including level of education, age, sex, economic status
and work status, which can guide interventions. Considering the high proportion of having multiple NCD risk factors, interventions are needed that target multiple, in particular modifiable, NCD risk factors, such as low physical activity and overweight/obesity. Cabo Verde can strengthen the implementation of its national policy for physical activity and food, including national physical activity communication campaigns and national mass participation events on physical activity, and in addition to promoting physical activity through community sports and for older adults, physical activity promotion can include workplaces, childcare settings, public open spaces and through walking and cycling. The national food policy can be strengthened by introducing sugarsweetened beverage tax, policy to limit saturated fatty acid intake, policy to introduce industrially produced trans fatty acids and policy to reduce the impact of marketing of foods and beverages high in saturated fats, trans fatty acids, free sugars or salt in children.

title: Behavioural and biological risk factors of non- communicable diseases among adults in Cabo Verde: a repeated cross- sectional study of the 2007 and 2020 national community- based surveys
